thread.title: Nebraska Game and Parks officials ask public to report any sightings of rare whooping cranes
thread.title_full: Nebraska Game and Parks officials ask public to report any sightings of rare whooping cranes - Winnipeg Free Press

author: The Associated Press
title: Nebraska Game and Parks officials ask public to report any sightings of rare whooping cranes
text:
LINCOLN, Neb. - The entire population of the continent's endangered whooping cranes is expected to migrate through Nebraska over the next several weeks, and Nebraska Game and Parks officials are asking the public to report any sightings of the birds.
The Nebraska Game and Parks Commission says information on crane sightings is used for whooping crane conservation and recovery efforts.
The rare cranes have features that distinguish them from the more common Sandhill crane. Whooping cranes are approximately 5 feet tall and fly with their neck outstretched. Adults are all white with the exception of black wing tips and reddish-black facial pattern.
Whooping cranes were near extinction in the early to mid-20th century. Through conservation efforts, the birds' numbers have increased slowly to an estimated 308.
